title: Passo Sella: Fabled rock of the Giro d’Italia
content:
Cyclist
Passo Sella: Fabled rock of the Giro d’Italia

As afternoon melts into evening in the Italian Dolomites, the grey limestone walls of the Sella massif blush a glorious shade of rose-red. It is a phenomenon that locals call enrosadira (literally ‘turning pink’, but so much more evocative in Italian). And on Stage 17 of the 1998 Giro d’Italia, on the storied slopes of the 2,240m Passo Sella, the jersey of Marco Pantani underwent the same magical rose-tinted transformation.

Cheered on by tricolore-waving tifosi, the Italian cyclist’s gloriously aggressive acceleration on the Passo Sella turned his jersey from the maglia verde of the mountains leader – which was only changed from green to blue in 2012 – into the iconic maglia rosa of the Giro leader. It was the first time Pantani, 28, had worn pink. And he would retain the jersey for the final five stages to claim an emotional Giro title and send the host nation into raptures.

Related Posts

Col de Peyresourde: A Tour de France institution

Why the Hardknott Pass is the hardest climb in England

Susten Pass: The supersized Swiss climb

It is just one of the historic scenes that have played out on the Passo Sella, a stunning climb near Alta Badia that borders Trentino and South Tyrol and connects Val di Fassa with Val Gardena. The Sella’s oxygen-starved hairpins torment the body but enchant the mind, unlocking sublime views of the fortress-shaped Sella and the sheer 3,181m wall of the Sassolungo.

Around 250 million years ago, these turrets and towers lay deep underwater, forming part of an ancient coral reef in the primordial ocean of Tethys. But today the roads to the Sella are caked in the sediment of cycling history, having appeared in the Giro 17 times, and hosted the heroics of riders from Gino Bartali in 1940 to Laurent Fignon in 1984 and Gilberto Simoni in 2000 – all of whom summited the Sella first.

Sella of stories

The roads to the Passo Sella soar from mountain meadows, past isolated wooden chalets, into a majestic limestone arena of rock-hewn towers and grey-white cliffs. The pass was built in the 1870s and first appeared in the Giro on Stage 17 in 1940, with Gino Bartali first over the top. That year, Bartali – a two-time Giro winner – was on the same Legnano team as 20-year-old wonderkid Fausto Coppi.

When Coppi punctured, Bartali waited. When Bartali had technical issues, the young tearaway tried to race on, until their sports director, Eberardo Pavesi, reined him in. Coppi later faded so badly on the punishing Sella that Bartali had to stuff snow down his jersey to revive him.

On Stage 19 of the 1953 Giro, the Sella saw a titanic battle between Coppi and Swiss rival Hugo Koblet. At first, Koblet soared ahead, then Coppi accelerated and dropped him near the summit. Koblet blasted by him on the descent, before Coppi sprinted to victory. Grainy footage of the Sella duel is available online.

On Stage 20 in 1984, French rider Laurent Fignon opened a 1min 35sec gap over the leaders when grinding up the Sella. His rival Francesco Moser – who went on to win the race – had to be pushed up the Sella by spectators.

Most recently, the pass appeared on Stage 14 in 2016, when Spaniard David López Garcia summited first. On three occasions (1969, 1976 and 1998) the high-altitude summit has marked the Cima Coppi – the highest point of the race – but it was that one in 1998 that everyone remembers best. The year of Marco Pantani.

The Pirate’s peak

The Giro served up a gruelling course that year, with 3,830km of racing. On Stage 17, the peloton faced a 217km mountain stage, from Asiago in Veneto to Selva in South Tyrol. Swiss racer Alex Zülle (Festina), buoyed by winning two Vuelta titles in 1996 and 1997, was wearing pink, and Russian Pavel Tonkov (Mapei), who won the Giro in 1996, was in second. Despite beginning the day almost four minutes behind, Pantani insisted, ‘Non è finite.’ It’s not over yet.

The race leaders made it to the mighty Marmolada together, where Tonkov cranked up the speed and Zülle snapped. But Pantani kept pace and later escaped with fellow Italian Giuseppe Guerini (Polti). Then, on the hairpins of the Sella – the final climb – the Italians gobbled up the breakaway and ruthlessly stretched their advantage.

Dressed in the blue and yellow shorts of his Mercatone Uno-Bianchi team, and the green jersey of the mountains leader, Pantani dashed over the top first, sending the Italian crowd wild. After the final descent, Guerini was gifted the stage, but Pantani had taken 4min 37sec out of Zülle and 2min 4sec out of Tonkov to seize the maglia rosa. On the podium, Pantani kissed the pink jersey.

‘I take risks and attack,’ he declared. ‘That’s why the tifosi love me.’

When he claimed the Giro title five days later, Italy descended into Pantani-mania. It was his heroics on the Sella that inspired him to glory, and he and this pass remain forever entwined.

Fangs and fissures

The Sella is strikingly picturesque when climbed in both directions. From Plan de Gralba in the north – the direction cyclists follow on the traffic-free Sellaronda Bike Days, held in June and September each year – the Sella involves a 5.4km ascent, with 369m of climbing, an average gradient of 6.8% and stabs at 12.5%.

After a short section through a forest of pine, larch and spruce, the road curls into open pastures that separate the fissure-etched wall of the Sassolungo from the fanged cliffs of the Sella. You ride past dramatic ledges, crags and rocky plateaux. On the final hairpins there are vertiginous drops into a rock-hewn arena that blends the colossal Sassolungo and the towering spires of the Torri del Sella in a spellbinding panorama.

From Canazei in the south – the direction riders take in the annual Maratona sportive – the Sella is a longer 11.4km climb, with 784m of climbing, an average gradient of 6.9% and maximum bursts of 8%. The snaking route is a riot of 23 hairpins, plus some soul-sapping straights.

The opening hairpins pile up like layers of a wedding cake, through dark forested terrain, into pristine mountain meadows decorated with cable cars, avalanche barriers and ski pistes. After the final leg-flaming bends, the road unlocks a vista of limestone peaks, with turrets resembling razor-sharp sabres and jagged ridges like the jaws of an alligator.

The Swiss-French architect Le Corbusier described the peaks here as ‘the most beautiful work of architecture ever seen’. Cyclists who chase the ghosts of Coppi and Pantani up the Passo Sella are unlikely to disagree.
